2020 DNC Convention Updates
Temporary Standing Committee Members
This August, Rhode Islanders will go to Milwaukee, Wisconsin for the 2020 Democratic National Convention. At the Convention, we'll formally select the Party's nominee for president and vice president.
It is a 4-day meeting and celebration of what the Democratic Party has accomplished and look to achieve in the future. In the days between, Convention delegates, alternates and members of the party conduct official party business. For years, that business has been done by the three Standing Committees of the Convention: Credentials, Platform and Rules. We are looking for 3 people to serve temporarily on these committees, until permanent members are selected by RI's DNC Convention delegation in June.
To apply, please send a letter of interest with your name, address, and phone number to [[URL REDACTED]] by 5 pm today. Applicants must also include a completed Pledge of Support Form, which can be downloaded by clicking here.
2020 DNC Convention Updates
PLEOs, At-Large Delegates, & Alternates
Interested in attending the 2020 Democratic National Convention?
The RIDP will be sending a delegation to Milwaukee, Wisconsin to participate in the Democratic National Convention
from August 17-20, 2020.
Rhode Island will be represented by 35 delegates and 2 alternates.
Candidates for Party Leaders and Elected Officials (PLEO), At-large delegate, and Alternate must submit a  Statement of Candidacy and Pledge of Support form.
Completed forms must be submitted via email to [[URL REDACTED]]

body_text:
Statement on the Passing of
Edna O'Neill Mattson
By Joseph M. McNamara, Chair of the R.I. Democratic Party
WARWICK, R.I. (March 23, 2020) – “It is with great sadness and heavy hearts that we’ve learned today of the passing of Edna O’Neill Mattson,” said Rhode Island Democratic Party Chair Joseph M. McNamara.
“Edna was our state’s Democratic National Committeewoman for decades and a legend for her fiery red hair and fiery personality, and her service to community. If the late Senator Ted Kennedy was the Lion of the Senate, then she surely was the Lioness of this state’s Democratic Party,” McNamara said.
“Everything Edna cared about, she cared deeply about: her beloved family, the Community College of Rhode Island, the Democratic Party, the Navy Relief Society and American Red Cross. She was the first woman Democratic town chair, a charter member of the state Democratic City and Town Chair Association, and a delegate to every National Democratic Convention since 1976,” he said.
“Edna proudly served this party her whole life, and fittingly ended it as our state’s Democratic National Committee woman,” McNamara. “We will miss her: there will never be another Edna.”
﻿Condolences may be sent to:
John & Annette Mattson
405 Lloyd Avenue
Providence, RI 02906

Statement on the Passing of Edna O'Neill Mattson
By Joseph M. McNamara, Chair of the R.I. Democratic Party
WARWICK, R.I. (March 23, 2020) – “It is with great sadness and heavy hearts that we’ve learned today of the passing of Edna O’Neill Mattson,” said Rhode Island Democratic Party Chair Joseph M. McNamara.
“Edna was our state’s Democratic National Committeewoman for decades and a legend for her fiery red hair and fiery personality, and her service to community. If the late Senator Ted Kennedy was the Lion of the Senate, then she surely was the Lioness of this state’s Democratic Party,” McNamara said.
“Everything Edna cared about, she cared deeply about: her beloved family, the Community College of Rhode Island, the Democratic Party, the Navy Relief Society and American Red Cross. She was the first woman Democratic town chair, a charter member of the state Democratic City and Town Chair Association, and a delegate to every National Democratic Convention since 1976,” he said.
“Edna proudly served this party her whole life, and fittingly ended it as our state’s Democratic National Committee woman,” McNamara. “We will miss her: there will never be another Edna.”

Gaspee Day
Everyone should know a little more about the tale of the HMS Gaspee, a British ship that met its demise in Narragansett Bay. It's a story that represents the grit and tenacity that define Rhode Islanders - and it's also a hell of a yarn.
Since we can't get together in person, Senator Whitehouse put together a video telling the story of the events in question. It's not quite the same as the in-person experience, but it's the next best thing.

Juneteenth
Today marks 155 years since the last enslaved Africans took their first step of freedom in Galveston, Texas. Mail Ballot Applications
Hard to believe it but we are just 40 days away from the November 3 primary election! One sure fire way to make sure you can safely cast your ballot this year is to file an application for a mail ballot.
All you have to do is fill out the application and send it to your local board of canvassers. What's better than that?!?
Applications are due on Tuesday October 13. To download a copy of the application, click here.
For more information on how to cast your ballot this November, click here.

Poll workers are an essential part of running elections and they are in short supply. Every city and town in the state could use a few good men and women willing to help make the November 3 general election smooth for every voter.

RHODE ISLAND (April 6, 2020) – Thanks to a partnership with CVS Health, free rapid COVID-19 tests are now available to all Rhode Islanders, at a drive-up site at Twin River Casino in Lincoln. Residents must register for an appointment first at [[URL REDACTED]] [[URL REDACTED]]
You will receive results on the spot for the first time, thanks to a new Abbott ID Now system. CVS is overseeing these free tests with licensed health care professionals from CVS Minute Clinic. It can provide positive results in as little as 5 minutes and negative results in 15 minutes, while you wait. Before you request the test, you should be exhibiting symptoms of the virus.
Rhode Island and Georgia are the only two states in the nation currently offering these tests. Speaker Mattiello offers his appreciation to CVS Health for stepping forward in this innovative partnership.

# LPRI's First-Ever Virtual Convention
The COVID-19 outbreak – and the world’s reaction to it – has changed everything about the way we function as a society and how we interact with each other and in groups. In the span of a few weeks – in some cases, literally overnight – policies and behaviors changed, and “social distancing” and “flatten the curve” became part of a new lexicon.
Among the recent changes to longstanding tradition is the way the Libertarian Party of Rhode Island held its annual convention on Monday, April 20, 2020: over Google Hangouts Meet. The virtual environment, combined with a simple but effective, anonymous real-time voting system, ensured efficient transaction of important party business while permitting safe social mingling before and after.
At the 2020 State Convention of the Libertarian Party of Rhode Island, Mike Rinaldi was re-elected vice chairman for a two-year term, Billy Hunt was re-elected to a two-year term as secretary, and Shawn Mizener was elected to the one-year term of member-at-large. The terms of Chairman Pat Ford and Treasurer Beth Richardson are in effect through 2021.
Chairman Ford called the convention to order and presided over the business meeting, including review, discussion, and votes to approve or reject various proposed amendments to the Bylaws. Bylaws, as newly amended, are available at [[URL REDACTED]]
The next MEET UP will also be virtual. There's a lot to discuss about the current status of the state's COVID-19 shut-down and just how and when to re-open the state. They call it a "new normal" but is it? Does it have to be? And what about the staggering economic impact this is having now and in the future?
Or maybe we keep it light and just enjoy each other's company. Being in separate locations does not have to alter that standard quality of our Meet-Ups!
So, put away your mask and come "hang out" with LPRI in Google Hang Outs on Monday, May 18 at this link.
You serve up your own beverage and snack food of choice, bring your topics and questions, and we'll serve up the latest news and info for open discussion starting at 7 p.m. Hope to "see" you there!
Support your freedom in three ways:
1\. Join the LPRI (invest in your liberty)
2\. Donate (added gifts are appreciated)
3\. Volunteer (give as much or as little time as you can spare)

# Libertarian Party vice-presidential candidate Spike Cohen will be appearing at Memorial Park in Providence on Tuesday, October 6.
The event will begin at 5 p.m. with an introductory speech given by local libertarian candidate William Hunt, who is running in District 68 for a seat in the Rhode Island House of Representatives. A victory for Hunt would make him the first libertarian elected to office in the state.
This will be followed by Cohen’s keynote speech and a question and answer session.
This event, which LPRI is co-hosting with the Rhode Island for Jorgensen campaign, is an opportunity to connect with the party on a national and local level. Come support Jo Jorgensen's presidential bid. Come learn more about where libertarians stand in Rhode Island and how you can do more to advance the party.
This event is free and tickets are not required. We hope to see you there!
Directions to the event:
Memorial Park is located on South Main Street in Providence. If traveling from the south, take I-95 north to exit 20 and follow Point Street to South Main Street. If traveling from the south, take I-95 north to exit 22A towards Memorial Boulevard.

# Happy New Year!
It's a big year ahead - RI General Assembly is back in session so our eagle eyes, led by Policy Director Shawn Mizener, are sharply focused on seeking out exploitative and liberty-robbing legislation in the blizzard of paper grandstanding we expect every year, but particularly in an election year. Already there is legislation against 3D-printed guns...
Speaking of election year, it's also another Presidential Election Year, and the battle lines are being drawn within the Libertarian Party in the most interesting ways. ICYMI (and not sure how you could), the biggest news locally has to be the announcement from former Republican mayor and US Senator, and former independent RI Governor, and former Democratic presidential candidate Lincoln Chafee that he has (within the past one year) relocated to Wyoming, registered with the Libertarian Party and promptly threw his hat into the ring for Libertarian Party candidate for president. President of the United States, yes. It's been a diverse and busy political career for Linc so far, and he shows no signs of slowing in 2020.
When local news and talk shows sought out Chairman Pat Ford for his comments, he said, "Welcome to the Party, Senator!"
He is not running for office himself, but Chairman Pat Ford will be busy this campaign season as well. Starting January 11, LPRI chairman will attend regional conventions as the elected alternate representative of the national committee. Nice way to advance advocacy for local party efforts while working to improve - and have a say - on the national party scene. Stay tuned for updates from or on behalf of the chairman on the newsblog at [[URL REDACTED]]
Actively participate in protecting your freedom - join us! Sign up to attend a public hearing, agree to call or write to elected officials, volunteer to get a local defender elected. Would you serve on a committee to organize events, corral volunteers, help research and track legislation? There are many opportunities to make a difference throughout the year. One of the first and easiest ways to make a difference is become a sustaining member of LPRI. Help support your freedom now.
January Meet-Up is at Murphy's Law in Pawtucket
Come hang out and get to know other libertarians. Join us at our monthly meet-up. A less formal, more social gathering, it's an ongoing opportunity to discuss issues and share ideas, ask questions, and network. Come and go as you please.
The LPRI meets on the third Monday of every month. We rotate to three different locations across the state - MURPHY'S LAW in Pawtucket, TICKETS in Middletown, and THE WOODS TAVERN in West Greenwich. Check the LPRI website, the Facebook event page, or track these emails to find a meet-up near you.
